etymology.description: phonetic: 延(延) (yán, "prolong") + semantic: 虫(虫) (chóng, "snake, insect") -> originally 蜑 -> 延 simplified to 疋 -> 蛋 ("egg")
etymology.interpretation: The character 蛋 refers to an egg, with the semantic component 虫(虫) (chóng, "snake, insect") indicating snake eggs, reinforced by the phonetic 延(延) (yán, "prolong"). The character 蜑 was the original non-contracted form, later simplified to 蛋 with 延 becoming 疋. This reflects the later coinage of the character, indicating it wasn't part of very early Chinese script.

examples.chinese: 早餐的时候(早餐的時候)，我吃了一个蛋(我吃了一個蛋)。
examples.pinyin: Zǎocān de shíhòu, wǒ chīle yīgè dàn.
examples.english: At breakfast, I ate an egg.

examples.chinese: 运动员因意外受伤(運動員因意外受傷)，他的蛋受了伤(他的蛋受了傷)。
examples.pinyin: Yùndòngyuán yīn yìwài shòushāng, tā de dàn shòule shāng.
examples.english: The athlete got injured in an accident, and his testicle was hurt.

examples.chinese: 那个常常临阵退缩的人被叫做蛋(那個常常臨陣退縮的人被叫做蛋)。
examples.pinyin: Nàgè chángcháng línzhèn tuìsuō de rén bèi jiào zuò dàn.
examples.english: That person who always shrinks in the face of danger is called a coward.
